text: I've said this a lot, but I mean it: there is a difference between expecting autocracy and accepting it. I don't accept it. I'll never accept it. And there are a lot of people who feel the same way. Curb your expectations -- but never curb your demands.
author: sarahkendzior

text: I'm re-upping old tweets not in an "I told you so" way, but because I'm tired of repeating myself, and I also need you to see that autocracy is predictable. Don't look for saviors: think for yourselves. Independent thought + ability to speak freely is nothing to take for granted.

text:

text: Most of these tips work are good for surviving natural disasters, and we're having those more frequently, so you can think of it as advice for that instead of other scenarios. Never hurts to be prepared; the worst that happens is you've got some extra supplies lying around.

text: I don't want to get into it. I'll just say it's always a good idea to have a supply of water and non-perishable food on hand, as well as first-aid kits, flashlights, batteries, etc. And cash. Make sure your passport is up to date if you plan on using it; expedite the renewal.
author: sarahkendzior

Yes. I'm not an expert and I also found the terms confusing because they were often used interchangeably.

But basically it's cause and effect. Global warming changes the climate, and each thing itt changes (sea levels etc), changes another thing, and it all gets destabilized.
author: sarahkendzior

text:
Global warming describes the increase in the earth's surface temperature caused by burning fossil fuels.

Climate change refers to the broader changes global warming caused: rising sea levels, ice caps melting, etc. It's a better term IMO because it describes changes beyond heat.

text:
Two separate numbers: orange and light blue, next to each other. But the combination creates a feeling, so 52 has its own quality.

I had a scheduled C-section for my second kid so I got to choose his birthday from two dates; I chose the date with the prettier color pattern
author: sarahkendzior

text:
Like, 5 is orange, and if you touched 5, it would feel like touching metal on a sunny day. It would be sharp and very warm. But none of this is anything I consciously think about when I see/hear 5. It's just sort of there: the quality of 5.

Again, this is why I avoided drugs
author: sarahkendzior

text: I want to say letters and numbers and notes have a texture you can't touch, but I realize that makes zero sense. It's like they have the feeling of a texture -- a richness or a thinness or a roughness -- but not each linked to distinct, named textures that exist in reality.
author: sarahkendzior

text:
E is green. The musical note E is also green. Number 3 and Wednesday are green too. Each letter of Wednesday has its own color, but the *concept* of Wednesday is green. Kind of like how an E chord is green-orange-yellow but as a whole, it's green.

This is why I avoided drugs
author: sarahkendzior

text: Yes it's from The View From Flyover Country
author: sarahkendzior

text: Oh man, I wish I had that skill. Sometimes I wonder if synesthesia cancels out the ability to tell left from right without effort, have any sense of direction, or find my keys. I misplace my shit constantly but I *can* affirm that E is green, so there's that...
author: sarahkendzior

text: It looks "wrong" but necessarily off-putting. It can still be interesting or pretty. I can think "Wow, they made A blue instead of red; how weird" and also think "That's such a pretty shade of blue." It doesn't bother me but I do notice when it doesn't match my default.
author: sarahkendzior

text: My first job out of college was at the New York Daily News. I was 21. I remember how impressed people would be, even though the job itself was drudgery. I quit when I was 24 and had to train myself to not equate my worth with my job. Once I was free of that, the world improved.
author: sarahkendzior

text: And occasionally it happens with really distinctive vocalists; their voice has its own color. Roy Orbison has a dark blue-purple voice the color of infinity
author: sarahkendzior

text: OMG I know that feeling. And when you dislike a song primarily for the color, it's like a visceral loathing. On the plus side, when you love a song because of the color, it's amazing. For me this happens most with classical music and metal -- esp electric guitar solos, esp Slash
author: sarahkendzior

text: My daughter has synesthesia too and we "debate" what colors letters are. My husband does not have it and thinks we're both nuts! I'm waiting to see if my son also has it; he's a little kid and makes bizarre stuff up to be funny so we can't tell if he's truly one of us yet

author: sarahkendzior

text: It's kind of cool. It might have made me a better writer and a better musician. But honestly I can't imagine what it's like to *not* have synesthesia. I was startled to find out it wasn't universal. I was like "Obviously A is red, how do you all not see that?!"
author: sarahkendzior

text:
I have synesthesia too, but not with taste. Letters, numbers, and musical notes have colors. When I struggle to remember a word, I can often still see the colors. When I hear music, I "hear" colors too.

I had no idea that everyone else did NOT have synesthesia until I was 12
